December 2020 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Determining the 
Direction of Social Assistance Reforms

Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support research to evaluate 
the economic and social welfare impacts of social assistance policies in the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC), and propose reform directions and policy options. Through empirical and theoretical 
studies  and  international  comparison,  the  TA  will  recommend  optimal  social  assistance 
expenditure and benefit levels, and develop policy tools to improve the social assistance system. 
The TA will produce knowledge products and build capacity among social protection policy 
makers. The TA is included in the list of projects agreed between the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and the Government of the PRC on 22 January 2020.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Aligning social policy with an evolving socioeconomic context. Rapid economic 
growth and sustained anti-poverty efforts, including targeted social assistance, have significantly 
reduced extreme poverty in the PRC. However, even before the impact of the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) pandemic of 2020, economic growth in the PRC had moderated. After 4 decades of 
rapid economic development and a dramatic increase in people’s living standards, gross domestic 
product (GDP) growth slowed from 6.7% in 2018 to 6.1% in 2019.2 Typically, social assistance 
policies should build on a country’s socioeconomic conditions and overall development goals. In 
the context of higher living standards and the expected eradication of extreme poverty by the end 
of 2020, inequality remains an issue and the concept of relative poverty becomes more relevant.3 
Social assistance policies in the PRC require new strategic choices, and the future direction of 
the reforms depends on a comprehensive understanding of the economic and social impacts of 
various social assistance policies. 
 
3.  Functions and features of the social assistance system. Key functions of the social 
assistance system include guaranteeing citizens’ basic livelihoods, promoting social equity, and 
maintaining social harmony and stability.4 The social assistance system includes a variety of 
policy tools for the poor—including cash transfers such as the dibao (minimum basic living 
guarantee); the tekun program for destitute people (formerly wubao); and special assistance for 
eligible poor families for education, health care, housing, and employment. Temporary assistance 
is granted for disaster relief in emergencies. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, the State 
Council issued new guidelines in August 2020 to refine the social assistance system, improve the 
targeting and adjustment of benefit levels, and expand the coverage of welfare programs.5 A new 
social  assistance  law  is  in the  State  Council’s  legislative  work  plan  for  2020.6 The  public 
consultation version of the draft law was posted online for review in September 2020. Once 
comments have been collected and addressed, the legislative body (the People’s Congress) will 
consider the draft law.  
 
4.  Social assistance programs. Dibao is the foundation of the social assistance system, 
providing unconditional cash transfers to urban and rural households with a per capita income 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 29 October 2020. 
2  ADB. 2020. Asian Development Outlook 2020: What Drives Innovation in Asia? Manila.  
3  ADB. 2020. Post-2020 Poverty Reduction Policy Options for the People’s Republic of China. Observations and 
Suggestions. No. 2020-03. Manila.  
4  Government of the PRC, State Council. 2014. Interim Measures for Social Assistance. Beijing. 
5  Government of the PRC, State Council. 2020. Opinions on Reforming and Improving the Social Assistance System. 
Beijing. 
6  International Labour Organization. 2020. Social Security Policy Monitor China, June–August 2020. Issue 3. European 
Union–China Project: Improving China’s Institutional Capacity Towards Universal Social Protection. Beijing.

2 
below the locally defined minimum standards. These standards vary by province, municipality, 
and urban and rural areas. As of April 2019, dibao had 9.6 million urban beneficiaries (1.1% of 
the  urban  population)  and  34.8  million  rural  beneficiaries  (6.2%  of  the  rural  population), 
comprising 3.2% of the PRC’s population.7 Over time, the standards have increased while the 
number of beneficiaries has declined. Nevertheless, dibao remains one of the largest social 
transfer programs in the world. The tekun program for the destitute complements the family-based 
dibao system, and is targeted at specific vulnerable groups (the elderly, persons with disabilities, 
and children under 16) who have no work, no other source of income, and no other support—also 
known as “the three nos.” As of April 2019, tekun covered about 4.50 million rural and 0.28 million 
urban  beneficiaries  (footnote  7).  Special  interim  assistance  for  low-income  families  covers 
education, medical care, housing, and employment.  
 
5.  Competing views of social assistance expenditure. The PRC’s comprehensive social 
assistance system covers various hardships and risks faced by the poor, but social assistance 
expenditure remains relatively low as a share of GDP (less than 1%) when compared to the 
average for emerging markets in Asia, all emerging markets, and the average across members 
of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.8 Competing schools of thought 
consider social assistance on the one hand as a required fiscal expenditure or a financial burden 
to meet the basic needs of low-income people; and on the other hand as a positive social and 
economic investment that plays a crucial role in reducing inequality, increasing consumption, 
stabilizing economic fluctuations, and promoting long-term sustainable economic development. 
These contrasting perspectives correspond to different social assistance and social protection 
policy development options and reform directions. 
 
6.  Determining expenditure levels. Social assistance programs generally require large 
fiscal expenditures. Lowering expenditure by reducing benefit levels could allow more public 
investment in other areas with potentially higher returns. Lower welfare benefits could also 
encourage  low-income  groups  to  provide  more  labor.  On  the  other  hand,  social  transfers 
(especially special assistance for medical care, education, and employment) can directly enable 
the  poor  to  invest more  in  human  capital, thereby  increasing the  country’s  human  capital 
accumulation and improving economic competitiveness. At the same time, since low-income 
people have a higher marginal propensity to consume, transfer payments increase consumption 
and can stabilize domestic demand. These different aspects should be considered in determining 
the  optimal  level  of  social  assistance.  Research  using the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-
operation and Development’s data sets suggests that different social expenditure schemes have 
different effects on poverty, inequality, and growth.9 This means policy makers have the possibility 
to target more accurately when deciding on social assistance schemes, with the goal of reducing 
poverty and inequality without negatively affecting GDP growth. 
 
7.  Knowledge gaps. Few researchers have studied the impact of social assistance on 
beneficiary welfare as well as inequality and economic development in the PRC. The impact 
channels of special or interim assistance programs (medical care, education, housing, and 
employment) on individuals and the economy may be different from the impact channels of direct 
cash transfers such as dibao. Comparing the PRC’s social assistance programs with similar ones 
in developed countries, e.g., in France or the United States, could provide useful lessons and 
 
7  Government of the PRC, Ministry of Civil Affairs. 2019. Monthly Report of Civil Affairs, April 2019 (in Chinese).  
8  International Monetary Fund. 2018. People’s Republic of China: 2018 Article IV Consultation—Press Release; Staff 
Report; Staff Statement and Statement by the Executive Director for the People’s Republic of China. IMF Country 
Report. No. 18/240. Washington, DC. 
9  E. Cammeraat. 2020. The Relationship between Different Social Expenditure Schemes and Poverty, Inequality and 
Economic Growth. International Social Security Review. 73 (2). pp. 101–123.

3 
recommendations to help clarify the direction of reforms and improve the programs’ design.10 The 
PRC’s Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) seeks tools to determine the optimal level of social 
assistance, with a focus on the three main programs: dibao, tekun, and interim assistance. 
 
8.  Strategic alignment and value addition. Strengthening social protection systems and 
service delivery is fundamental to the ADB Strategy 2030 operational priority of addressing 
remaining poverty and reducing inequalities.11 By promoting gender balance among participants 
of capacity development activities, the TA also addresses the ADB operational priority of gender 
equality and women’s empowerment. The TA is aligned with the five Sustainable Development 
Goals that explicitly mention social protection.12 The TA will build on the long history of ADB 
cooperation with the PRC on social protection and specifically social assistance. The TA program 
of the past decade has supported analytical work to inform the development of cash transfer 
programs and the establishment of the urban poverty line; assessment of the impacts of the hukou 
(household registration) system on migrant workers and their families; assessment of social 
protection financing, benefits, and targeting; development of social work services for vulnerable 
groups (older persons and children); and contracting of social organizations for service delivery, 
among others. This TA builds on a 2020 TA completion report recommending further ADB support 
for social assistance reforms.13  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: social assistance strengthened, basic living 
standards guaranteed, social justice promoted, and social harmony and stability maintained 
(footnote 4). The TA will have the following outcome: evidence-based social assistance policy 
toolbox improved.14 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output  1:  Analytical  knowledge  products  developed.  The  TA  will  analyze  the 
relationship between social assistance and economic development, and propose a scientific 
method to determine the level and coverage of social assistance. It will analyze the economic and 
welfare impacts of social assistance from the micro and macro perspective, including theoretical 
and empirical studies. The micro perspective includes the programs’ impact on consumption, 
inequality, health, and education. TA experts will construct a macrostructural model that includes 
the behaviors of individuals, enterprises, and governments to determine the optimal assistance 
levels of social assistance programs from a general equilibrium perspective. A counterfactual 
analysis will evaluate the impacts of several social assistance programs and assistance levels 
under different economic development stages. This will help predict which level of assistance can 
maximize both welfare and economic development. The TA will also undertake a literature review, 
 
10  The French subsistence allowance has expanded since its introduction in the late 1980s, causing enormous pressure 
on finances. Proposed reforms have had varying degrees of success. The extensive social protection system of the 
United States includes highly targeted social assistance for poor families. The PRC’s Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) 
proposes exploring several aspects to inform reforms to the PRC system.  
11 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
12  Social protection is key to achieving Sustainable Development Goals 1 (no poverty), 3 (good health and well-being), 
5 (gender equality), 8 (decent work and economic growth), and 10 (reduced inequalities). 
13 ADB. 2020. Technical Assistance Completion Report: Improving Efficiency in Public Service Procurement, Delivery, 
and Financing in the People’s Republic of China. Manila.    
14  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
examine national case studies, and assess social assistance systems in selected developed 
countries to draw lessons for the PRC. 
 
11.  Output 2: Social assistance policy makers’ capacity built. Utilizing the data from 
output 1, output 2 will include a series of seminars and workshops involving stakeholders across 
government agencies working on social assistance. International and national experts may be 
engaged as resource persons on specific topics as needed. This output also includes the 
production of online learning materials, and an international study visit to an ADB member country 
or countries.15 An understanding of the TA findings, recommendations, and policy tools will 
support social assistance policies, planning, and implementation. MOCA policy makers will be 
able to propose the development direction and potential reforms of social assistance policies, 
suggest optimal social assistance benefit levels, and recommend improvements to the design of 
social assistance in the PRC.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $330,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are  listed  in  Appendix  2.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart staff, access to data as appropriate to the TA, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The executing agency will be MOCA. The implementing agencies will be two MOCA 
departments: the Department of Social Assistance and the Center for the Identification and 
Guidance of Low-Income Families. ADB will administer the TA. Implementation arrangements are 
summarized in the table.

15  This activity will depend on the lifting of COVID-19 related travel restrictions. If travel is still not possible by late 2021, 
a virtual international symposium or other online options for an international learning experience will be explored.

5 
14.  Consulting services. Individual consultants will be recruited to provide 2 person-months 
of international and 26 person-months of national consulting services in the fields of economics 
and social protection.16 ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions. For maximum flexibility and demand-driven response in an evolving policy 
context,  ADB  will  also  engage  national  and/or  international  experts  for  resource  person 
assignments as needed and agreed with the executing agency during implementation.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Determining the Direction of Social Assistance 
Reforms, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
 
16 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Appendix 1  7 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.    Analytical knowledge products developed 
1.1  Develop a detailed research plan, working closely with the implementing agencies, to be finalized 
and approved at the inception workshop (Q1 2021) 
1.2  Review the national and international literature on the welfare effects and economic impacts of 
social transfers, and produce sub-report 1 (literature review) (Q1–Q2 2021) 
1.3  Study the micro and macro impacts of social assistance programs and undertake a general 
equilibrium analysis of the economic and welfare effect of social assistance to determine the optimal 
level, with counterfactual analysis, and produce sub-report 2 (economic analysis) (Q2–Q4 2021)  
1.4   Undertake international and national case studies to produce sub-report 3 (international case 
studies) and sub-report 4 (national case studies), with lessons and policy recommendations                    
(Q2–Q4 2021)  
1.5   Produce and disseminate knowledge products, including academic papers and policy briefs, based 
on each sub-report; and a final report with 4 sub-reports, according to the research plan (Q3 2021–
Q4 2022) 
1.6   Work with MOCA to disseminate the results to the public in an easily understandable and accessible 
format, including articles in newspapers or periodicals (Q3–Q4 2022) 
2.    Social assistance policy makers’ capacity built 
2.1  Organize TA inception (Q1 2021), midterm (Q4 2021), and final workshops (Q4 2022) 
2.2  Develop and host a seminar series on topics related to social assistance policy (Q3 2021–Q2 2022) 
2.3  Organize an international study visit to an ADB member country (Q2 2022) 
2.4   Produce online learning materials (e.g., lectures and presentations) and post them on the MOCA 
website (Q3 2022)

ADB: $300,000 (TASF-other sources)
